items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Torksey and Gainsborough river gauges as a result of high tides.  Flooding is possible during the high tides over the next few days.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road, Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith, Trent Wharfage and Gainsborough Railway Bridge.  Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated on Tuesday evening, 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. The higher water levels will continue through today, Tuesday 4th January, and the flood alert is expected to stay in force for the next few days. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update messages when necessary. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 5th January.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Cae Howel river gauges as a result of heavy rain and showers over the last week. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. 
At 8am today, Tuesday 04/01/22 the level at the Cae Howel gauge was 4.0m and steady. 
Further showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated 10am on Wednesday 05/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rain and showers over the past week. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further light showers are forecast over the next 24 hours and we expect river levels to remain high for the next couple of days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on Wednesday 05/01/22 or if the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. The higher water levels will continue through today, Tuesday 4th January, and the flood alert is expected to stay in force until Thusday 6th January. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 5th January.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall and showers over the past week. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. River levels will remain high for the next few days, as further showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 10am on Wednesday 05/01/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. The higher water levels will continue through today, Tuesday 4th January, and the flood alert is expected to stay in force until Thusday 6th January. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 5th January.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: High water levels with sea spray are forecast as a result of high tides and increased wind speeds. First forecast high water is 20:15 on 4/1/22 with a level of 6:24 mAOD and a Force 6 North Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 08:30 on 5/1/22 with a level of 6.40 mAOD and a Force 5 North Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level; for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Coastal conditions should ease for the 5/1/22 high tide at 21:00. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 11:00 tomorrow on Wednesday, 5/1/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today, 04/01/2022 between 5:00PM and 6:15PM. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Bridlington to Barmston, in particular around Bridlington Harbour, where Flood Warnings are in force. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are falling slowly on the lower River Ray. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is possible today (04/01/22), particularly in the Islip area. 
The forecast this morning (04/01/22) is for showers, clearing to leave a mainly dry afternoon and evening. 
River levels in the Islip area are falling slowly, but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. River levels upstream of Lower Arncott are now below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.
This message will be updated this evening, 04/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Flooding is possible at the North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey, including Scarborough between 4:15PM and 6:30PM on 04/01/2022. Areas most at risk include low spots around North and South Bay in Scarborough, including the Spa complex. We are expecting higher than normal tides, combined with strong winds which will create large waves over the next 2 days, and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Flooding is possible at the North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton between between 5:30PM and 7:45PM on 04/01/2022. Areas most at risk include low spots around Hornsea North Promenade. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington - Harbour Road and Floral Pavilion
items.message: This flood warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days, combined with large waves, so please avoid coastal frontages,  and as a result of this we may issue further alerts/warnings in the coming days.

items.description: Lower River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise as a result of a large tidal surge. Minor flooding of low lying land along the River Medway is expected between 13:00 and 15:30 this afternoon, 04/01/22.  We expect flooding to affect the riverside footpaths in the Maidstone area from Lock Meadow to Allington Lock. River levels are expected to peak in Maidstone around high tide at 13:15. Property flooding is not expected. Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides at 12:45 on 05/01/22.  We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are prepared to respond if required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near the River Medway. This message will be updated this evening, 04/01/22, or as the situation changes. Please remain aware of your local situation.

items.description: River Thame and Chalgrove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Thame in response to recent rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue today (04/01/22) especially around the Thame Bridge area. 
The forecast this morning (04/01/22) is for showers, clearing to leave a mainly dry afternoon and evening. 
River levels continue to slowly rise in the Thame Bridge area. Levels in the Dorchester and Stadhampton areas remain high but steady. River levels will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, some of which will be flooded.  
This message will be updated this evening, 04/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. The forecast this evening (03/01/22) is mainly dry with some scattered showers overnight. Some showers are forecast in the early hours of tomorrow morning (04/01/22) clearing to leave a mostly dry day tomorrow. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next few days however, we do not expect this to have any significant impact on the levels at the Welney Causeway.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 11:00 AM on 05/01/2022. The Flood Alert will be in force for 2 hours before and after the high water time.  Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. Our incident response staff have been checking defences. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please avoid flooded footpaths in the area during high tides. This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 05/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Welney Causeway in Norfolk
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next few days, however, we do not expect this to have any significant impact on the levels at the Welney Causeway.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Tide levels are now reducing and forecast to be lower than seen Tuesday lunchtime. In combination with moderate winds and a decrease in wave height, the risk of flooding has reduced. Small amounts of water might still affect land, fields and Climping Street Car Park at the peak of each tide, but the risk of flooding to properties is now very low. We continue to monitor the forecast and we will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

Flooding is possible at the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea between 5:30PM and 7:30PM on 04/01/2022. Areas most at risk include low spots around Kilnsea and Spurn Point. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The Thames Barrier is expected to close today for the predicted high water at 15:30 on 04/01/22. We are not currently planning to close the Thames Barrier for the high tide overnight at 03:45 on 05/01/22. and this Flood Alert message will be updated by 19:00 on 04/01/22 with the forecast river levels.   

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 110 cubic metres per second and is falling slowly. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 04/01/22, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
The tides for this afternoon (04/01/2022) and tomorrow morning (05/01/2022) are not expected to reach the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A series of high tides is due in the Severn Estuary until Wednesday evening the 5/1/22. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. 
Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 3.2m to 3.5m at 22:45 on 04/01/22. 
Flooding is not expected in any other gauge locations. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 23:30 on 04/01/22, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  The high tide this evening is expected to be high but is not forecast to reach the threshold for Flood Alerts. 
We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

Flooding is possible at the North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including Sandsend and tidal River Esk between 4:15PM and 5:45PM on 04/01/2022. Areas most at risk include low spots around Staithes Harbour and Whitby Harbour New Quay Road. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. items.description: Tweed estuary
items.message: Strong winds and high tides are again forecast to cause wave overtopping and spray at Berwick Between the Bridges on the Tweed Estuary. Tides will be at their highest between 15:00 and 17:30, this afternoon, 04/01/2022, and again between 03:45 and 06:00, tomorrow morning, 05/01/2022. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply up to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. Property flooding is not expected. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 18:00 today, 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
Tidal flooding near the South Humber Bank from Whitton to South Ferriby
items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in large waves and a tidal surge moving down the East Coast of England over the next couple of days. This will lead to high tidal levels along The South Humber Bank, between Whitton and South Ferriby. The time and date of the forecast high water is 18:45 on Tuesday 4th January 2022 and 07:30 on Wednesday 5th January 2022, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn’t likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray, and wave splash may cause localised pooling of water behind the sea defences. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, have staff in the field checking defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal flooding of areas near the Lincolnshire coastline
items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in large waves and a tidal surge moving down the East Coast of England over the next couple of days. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along along the East Coast, between Humberston to Gibraltar Point. The time and date of the forecast high water is 18:45 on Tuesday 4th January 2022 and 07:30 on Wednesday 5th January 2022, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash may cause localised pooling of water behind the sea defences. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn’t likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 6:00pm and 9:00pm on Tuesday 4th January. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.83 mAODN at 7:30pm, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.78m above tide tables, wind Force 6, westerly. mAODN is height above average sea level, (for more info refer to local tide tables).  The next few tides are also forecast to reach flood alert.  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated on the flood risk.  This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Tuesday 4th January.

items.description: South Devon Estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced. Take care near coastal paths and promenades.
The Environment Agency will continue to monitor the situation and issue any further updates as necessary.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 6pm and 9pm this evening, Tuesday 4th January. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.83 mAODN at 7:30pm, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.78m above tide tables, wind Force 6, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The next few tides are also forecast to reach Flood Alert.  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.  This message will be updated by 9pm tonight, Tuesday 4th January.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 9:30pm and 11:30pm  tonight, Tuesday 4th January. Tides are forecast to be higher than expected, due to weather conditions during spring tides. We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.93 mAODN at 10:30pm, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.8m above tide tables, wind Force 7, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The tide at 11:15am tomorrow is also currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.  We will update this message by 10am, Wednesday 5th January.

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.93 mAODN at 10:30pm, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.8m above tide tables, wind Force 7, westerly. mAODN is height above average sea level, (for more info refer to local tide tables).  The tide at 11:15am tomorrow is also currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:45am and 2:45pm on Tuesday 4th January. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 3.01 mAODN at 12:45pm, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.82m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). The next few tides are also forecast to reach flood alert. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:45am and 14:45pm on Tuesday 4th January. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 3.01 mAODN at 12:45am, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.82m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). The next few tides are also forecast to reach flood alert. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15am and 3:15pm on Tuesday 4th January. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low-lying land between the Fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 4.07 mAODN at 1:15pm, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.94m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). The next couple of tides are also forecast to be Flood Warnings, but we will send new messages before each high tide. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.

Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.04 mAODN at 12:45pm, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.76m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. items.description: Langstone to Emsworth Harbour
items.message: The tide level will remain a little elevated over the next couple of days, but overall the situation is improving, and no further impacts are currently expected.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: A large tidal surge is expected to affect the foreshore from Ramsgate to Kingsdown tomorrow lunchtime, Tuesday 04/01/22, as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 11:30 and 12:00 tomorrow, Tuesday 04/01/22, with high tide at 11:45. Flooding to roads and low lying land is expected at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of high tide. We expect flooding to affect coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea. Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides at 12:45 on 05/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon, 04/01/22, or as the situation changes. Please remain aware of your local situation. For those that use it, the astronomical water level will be 3.07m AOD and the total water level will be 3.76m AOD.

items.description: Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Flooding is possible between 6:30PM and 8:00PM on 04/01/2022. Areas most at risk include low spots around Hessle Haven, and Hessle Foreshore and North Ferriby. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. The new flood gates around Hessle foreshore have been closed and will remain closed for the next few days until the high tidal levels pass. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes

items.description: North Sea at Whitby Harbour
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Waves and spray combined with high tidal levels are forecast to overtop coastal frontages in Hornsea and could affect North Promenade, Marine Drive, South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck between 5:00PM and 7:30PM on 04/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Coastal floodgates in Hornsea have been closed. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Consider activating any property flood protection products if you have them. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Dartford to Allhallows
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide expected today, Tuesday the 4th of January, as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 11:15 to 15:15 today, with high tide expected at 13:15. Areas of concern include Royal Pier Road in Gravesend and low lying land nearest the sea.

Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tide at 14:15 tomorrow, the 05/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are checking our defences and structures and are prepared to respond if required.
 
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. For those that use it, the astronomical water level for the 13:15 tide recorded at Sheerness will be 3.01 mAOD and the forecast total water level will be 3.85 mAOD. The wind will be a force 5 Northerly wind. This message will be updated this afternoon or as the situation changes.

items.description: Thorney Island to Bracklesham
items.message: Tide levels are now reducing and forecast to be lower than seen Tuesday lunchtime. In combination with moderate winds and a decrease in wave height, the risk of flooding has reduced. With none, or minimal flood impacts expected. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 01:00 Wednesday morning 05/01/2022 will be 4.97 metres Chart Datum (2.23 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Dartford Creek and The Mardyke to the Thames Barrier
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Barking and Dagenham, Bexley, Greater London, Greenwich, Havering, Kent, Newham, Thurrock

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides and a closure of the Thames Barrier.

Water will be maintained within the downstream network of flood defences, which include river walls, embankments and flood gates, however flooding of low lying footpaths and open spaces is possible for 1-2 hours around high tide.

The forecast high tide at the Thames Barrier is at 14:15 on 04/01/22.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground ensuring all flood gates are closed.

Members of the public are advised to avoid floodwater and also to keep abreast of updates to the forecast as further Thames Barrier closures are possible.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 04/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Medway and Medway estuary
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been issued due to the high tide expected today, Tuesday the 4th of January, as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. The tide will be high  between 11:15 to 15:15 today, with high tide expected at 13:15. We expect flooding to affect locations nearest the estuary, in particular around Lower Upnor, Canal Road Strood and outer parts of the Medway Estuary.

Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tide at 14:15 tomorrow, the 05/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are checking our defences and structures and are prepared to respond when required.

Please take action to protect yourself and your property if you believe you are at risk. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads near the water. For those that use it, the astronomical water level for the 13:15 tide recorded at Sheerness will be 3.01mAOD and the forecast total water level will be 3.85mAOD. The wind will be a force 5 Northerly wind. This message will be updated this afternoon or as the situation changes.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
Strong winds and high tides are forecast to cause wave overtopping and spray at Beadnell and Newbiggin Bay today, 04/01/2022. Overtopping is expected at Beadnell Harbour Road North this afternoon between 14:30 and 18:00, and at Newbiggin Bay North Promenade between 15:15 and 18:00. 
Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply up to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Property flooding is not expected. The flood gates at Warkworth will not be closed. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 18:00 today, 04/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Bacton to Ostend, including Walcott
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely between 5:15pm and 9:15pm this evening, Tuesday 4th January. Tides are higher than expected, due to weather conditions during spring tides.  Areas most at risk are Sea View, Ann Stannard Way, Keswick Way, and Walcott Rd. The Coast Rd, St Helens Rd, Helena Rd, Poplar Dr, Archibald Rd, Lynton Rd, The Crescent and Ostend Place in Walcott. Seaview Crescent, Ostend Gap, Ostend Rd and Horizon Views. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Cromer of 3.10 mAODN at 7:15pm, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.76m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The next tide is also currently forecast to be a Flood Warning. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.  We will update this message by 9pm tonight, Tuesday 4th January.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Caister to Gorleston, including Great Yarmouth
items.message:
This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 8:45pm and 10:45pm on Tuesday 4th January. Tides are forecast to be higher than expected, due to weather conditions during spring tides. We expect high tide levels at Gorleston-on-Sea and water on towpaths and quaysides throughout Great Yarmouth. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Great Yarmouth of 1.92 mAODN at 9:45pm, Tuesday 4th January, which is 0.58m above tide tables, wind Force 6, westerly. mAODN is height above average sea level, (for more info refer to local tide tables).  

The tide at 11am on Wednesday 5th January is also currently forecast to be a Flood Alert, we will send a new message before that tide. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.  We will update this message by 10am Wednesday 5th January.
